title: How to Make Mini Pallet Coasters

steps.headline: Cut the ends off of 12 craft sticks.
steps.description: Ideally, the craft sticks should each be 4 inches (10 cm) long. Measure and mark the craft sticks with a pen or pencil first, then cut them using sharp scissors or a craft blade.

steps.headline: Dye the craft sticks with coffee or black tea, if desired.
steps.description: Brew a cup of black coffee or black tea, and pour it into a deep mug. Place the craft sticks into the mug, wait 5 minutes, then pull them out. Allow the sticks to air dry or speed the process up with a hairdryer. Don't add any milk to the coffee or tea. The sticks need to be completely submerged. If they aren't, add more coffee/tea, or find a deeper mug. You can also rotate the sticks after 2 minutes and 30 seconds.

steps.headline: Arrange 2 craft sticks so that they are parallel to each other.
steps.description: Place the sticks vertically, so that they make the number 11. The outer edges should be about 4 inches (10 cm) apart. This will eventually make the bottom of your pallet.

steps.headline: Hot glue 3 craft sticks horizontally across the first 2 sticks.
steps.description: Place a drop of hot glue on the top edge of each vertical craft stick. Turn a craft stick on its side, and press it into the glue. Repeat the process with a second stick for the bottom edges, and a third stick for the middle. You will have something that looks like a square. If the 2 vertical craft sticks are too far apart, push them closer together before you glue the horizontal craft sticks down. If they are too close, push them further apart. Make sure that the horizontal 2 craft sticks are on their skinny sides, not their wide/flat sides. This will make your pallet look more like a pallet and less like a picture frame.

steps.headline: Hot glue 7 craft sticks vertically across the 3 horizontal sticks.
steps.description: Hot glue a craft stick on the left and right edges of the horizontal craft sticks, flat-side-down. You want them to match up with the first, vertical set of craft sticks. Hot glue 1 more craft stick to the center, then 2 more on each side. Space the craft sticks as evenly as you can. Make sure that you are placing all of these craft sticks flat-side-down.

steps.headline: Use a silver marker to draw tiny nails, if desired.
steps.description: Make 2 tiny dots on each end of your 7 craft sticks. The dots should be side-by-side and parallel to the end of each stick. You don't have to do this, but it will make your pallet look more pallet-like!

steps.headline: Cut 7 craft sticks into 4 in (10 cm) lengths.
steps.description: Use a ruler and a pen or pencil to mark off the rounded ends of each craft stick. The marks should be 4 inches (10 cm) apart. Cut along the marks using scissors or a craft blade.

steps.headline: Cut a balsa wood stick into three 4 in (10 cm) lengths.
steps.description: Get a square (not round), ⁄8 in (0.95 cm) thick balsa wood stick. Cut it into 3 smaller sticks, each 4 inches (10 cm) long. This will make the sides and middle of your pallet. If you can't find a balsa wood stick: cut 4 craft sticks into 4 in (10 cm) lengths. Glue them together in a stack with liquid glue. Make 3 of these stacks.

steps.headline: Sand all of the cut ends smooth, if desired.
steps.description: Real pallets aren't always nicely finished, so you can skip this step and move onto the next one if you want a more realistic or rustic coaster. If you want a nicer finish, however, you should sand all of the cut ends on your craft and balsa wood sticks smooth. Use a fine-grit sandpaper for this. If you stacked and glued craft sticks together, be sure to sand the side edges smooth as well.

steps.headline: Stain the craft sticks and craft sticks with coffee.
steps.description: Brew a cup of coffee, then place all of your sticks into it. Leave them there for about 5 minutes, then pull them out. Allow the sticks to dry completely before moving on. Instead of dyeing the sticks, you can cover them with strips of patterned washi tape. Alternatively, you can paint the craft sticks and balsa wood sticks using acrylic paint. White would give you a nice finish.

steps.headline: Arrange the balsa wood sticks to look like the number 111.
steps.description: The outside edges of the first and last stick should be 4 inches (10 cm) apart. This will ensure that your craft sticks will lay neatly on top of them. The middle stick should be centered as much as possible.

steps.headline: Hot glue the 7 craft sticks horizontally across the balsa wood sticks.
steps.description: Place a drop of hot glue on the top edge of each balsa wood stick, then set a craft stick on top, wide/flat-side down. Repeat for the bottom edges. Add a third stick in the middle. Finish off with 2 craft sticks to either side of the middle stick.

steps.headline: Draw tiny nails with a silver marker.
steps.description: Simply make 2 dots on each end of your 7 craft sticks. If you covered them with washi tape, a black marker might stand out better.

text: Crafting a Simple Pallet Cut the ends off of 12 craft sticks. Ideally, the craft sticks should each be 4 inches (10 cm) long. Measure and mark the craft sticks with a pen or pencil first, then cut them using sharp scissors or a craft blade. Dye the craft sticks with coffee or black tea, if desired. Brew a cup of black coffee or black tea, and pour it into a deep mug. Place the craft sticks into the mug, wait 5 minutes, then pull them out. Allow the sticks to air dry or speed the process up with a hairdryer. Don't add any milk to the coffee or tea. The sticks need to be completely submerged. If they aren't, add more coffee/tea, or find a deeper mug. You can also rotate the sticks after 2 minutes and 30 seconds. Arrange 2 craft sticks so that they are parallel to each other. Place the sticks vertically, so that they make the number 11. The outer edges should be about 4 inches (10 cm) apart. This will eventually make the bottom of your pallet. Hot glue 3 craft sticks horizontally across the first 2 sticks. Place a drop of hot glue on the top edge of each vertical craft stick. Turn a craft stick on its side, and press it into the glue. Repeat the process with a second stick for the bottom edges, and a third stick for the middle. You will have something that looks like a square. If the 2 vertical craft sticks are too far apart, push them closer together before you glue the horizontal craft sticks down. If they are too close, push them further apart. Make sure that the horizontal 2 craft sticks are on their skinny sides, not their wide/flat sides. This will make your pallet look more like a pallet and less like a picture frame. Hot glue 7 craft sticks vertically across the 3 horizontal sticks. Hot glue a craft stick on the left and right edges of the horizontal craft sticks, flat-side-down. You want them to match up with the first, vertical set of craft sticks. Hot glue 1 more craft stick to the center, then 2 more on each side. Space the craft sticks as evenly as you can. Make sure that you are placing all of these craft sticks flat-side-down. Use a silver marker to draw tiny nails, if desired. Make 2 tiny dots on each end of your 7 craft sticks. The dots should be side-by-side and parallel to the end of each stick. You don't have to do this, but it will make your pallet look more pallet-like! Creating a Fancy Pallet Cut 7 craft sticks into 4 in (10 cm) lengths. Use a ruler and a pen or pencil to mark off the rounded ends of each craft stick. The marks should be 4 inches (10 cm) apart. Cut along the marks using scissors or a craft blade. Cut a balsa wood stick into three 4 in (10 cm) lengths. Get a square (not round), ⁄8 in (0.95 cm) thick balsa wood stick. Cut it into 3 smaller sticks, each 4 inches (10 cm) long. This will make the sides and middle of your pallet. If you can't find a balsa wood stick: cut 4 craft sticks into 4 in (10 cm) lengths. Glue them together in a stack with liquid glue. Make 3 of these stacks. Sand all of the cut ends smooth, if desired. Real pallets aren't always nicely finished, so you can skip this step and move onto the next one if you want a more realistic or rustic coaster. If you want a nicer finish, however, you should sand all of the cut ends on your craft and balsa wood sticks smooth. Use a fine-grit sandpaper for this. If you stacked and glued craft sticks together, be sure to sand the side edges smooth as well. Stain the craft sticks and craft sticks with coffee. Brew a cup of coffee, then place all of your sticks into it. Leave them there for about 5 minutes, then pull them out. Allow the sticks to dry completely before moving on. Instead of dyeing the sticks, you can cover them with strips of patterned washi tape. Alternatively, you can paint the craft sticks and balsa wood sticks using acrylic paint. White would give you a nice finish. Arrange the balsa wood sticks to look like the number 111. The outside edges of the first and last stick should be 4 inches (10 cm) apart. This will ensure that your craft sticks will lay neatly on top of them. The middle stick should be centered as much as possible. Hot glue the 7 craft sticks horizontally across the balsa wood sticks. Place a drop of hot glue on the top edge of each balsa wood stick, then set a craft stick on top, wide/flat-side down. Repeat for the bottom edges. Add a third stick in the middle. Finish off with 2 craft sticks to either side of the middle stick. Draw tiny nails with a silver marker. Simply make 2 dots on each end of your 7 craft sticks. If you covered them with washi tape, a black marker might stand out better.
sentences: Crafting a Simple Pallet Cut the ends off of 12 craft sticks.
Ideally, the craft sticks should each be 4 inches (10 cm) long.
Measure and mark the craft sticks with a pen or pencil first, then cut them using sharp scissors or a craft blade.
Dye the craft sticks with coffee or black tea, if desired.
Brew a cup of black coffee or black tea, and pour it into a deep mug.
Place the craft sticks into the mug, wait 5 minutes, then pull them out.
Allow the sticks to air dry or speed the process up with a hairdryer.
Don't add any milk to the coffee or tea.
The sticks need to be completely submerged.
If they aren't, add more coffee/tea, or find a deeper mug.
You can also rotate the sticks after 2 minutes and 30 seconds.
Arrange 2 craft sticks so that they are parallel to each other.
Place the sticks vertically, so that they make the number 11.
The outer edges should be about 4 inches (10 cm) apart.
This will eventually make the bottom of your pallet.
Hot glue 3 craft sticks horizontally across the first 2 sticks.
Place a drop of hot glue on the top edge of each vertical craft stick.
Turn a craft stick on its side, and press it into the glue.
Repeat the process with a second stick for the bottom edges, and a third stick for the middle.
You will have something that looks like a square.
If the 2 vertical craft sticks are too far apart, push them closer together before you glue the horizontal craft sticks down.
If they are too close, push them further apart.
Make sure that the horizontal 2 craft sticks are on their skinny sides, not their wide/flat sides.
This will make your pallet look more like a pallet and less like a picture frame.
Hot glue 7 craft sticks vertically across the 3 horizontal sticks.
Hot glue a craft stick on the left and right edges of the horizontal craft sticks, flat-side-down.
You want them to match up with the first, vertical set of craft sticks.
Hot glue 1 more craft stick to the center, then 2 more on each side.
Space the craft sticks as evenly as you can.
Make sure that you are placing all of these craft sticks flat-side-down.
Use a silver marker to draw tiny nails, if desired.
Make 2 tiny dots on each end of your 7 craft sticks.
The dots should be side-by-side and parallel to the end of each stick.
You don't have to do this, but it will make your pallet look more pallet-like!
Creating a Fancy Pallet Cut 7 craft sticks into 4 in (10 cm) lengths.
Use a ruler and a pen or pencil to mark off the rounded ends of each craft stick.
The marks should be 4 inches (10 cm) apart.
Cut along the marks using scissors or a craft blade.
Cut a balsa wood stick into three 4 in (10 cm) lengths.
Get a square (not round), ⁄8 in (0.95 cm) thick balsa wood stick.
Cut it into 3 smaller sticks, each 4 inches (10 cm) long.
This will make the sides and middle of your pallet.
If you can't find a balsa wood stick: cut 4 craft sticks into 4 in (10 cm) lengths.
Glue them together in a stack with liquid glue.
Make 3 of these stacks.
Sand all of the cut ends smooth, if desired.
Real pallets aren't always nicely finished, so you can skip this step and move onto the next one if you want a more realistic or rustic coaster.
If you want a nicer finish, however, you should sand all of the cut ends on your craft and balsa wood sticks smooth.
Use a fine-grit sandpaper for this.
If you stacked and glued craft sticks together, be sure to sand the side edges smooth as well.
Stain the craft sticks and craft sticks with coffee.
Brew a cup of coffee, then place all of your sticks into it.
Leave them there for about 5 minutes, then pull them out.
Allow the sticks to dry completely before moving on.
Instead of dyeing the sticks, you can cover them with strips of patterned washi tape.
Alternatively, you can paint the craft sticks and balsa wood sticks using acrylic paint.
White would give you a nice finish.
Arrange the balsa wood sticks to look like the number 111.
The outside edges of the first and last stick should be 4 inches (10 cm) apart.
This will ensure that your craft sticks will lay neatly on top of them.
The middle stick should be centered as much as possible.
Hot glue the 7 craft sticks horizontally across the balsa wood sticks.
Place a drop of hot glue on the top edge of each balsa wood stick, then set a craft stick on top, wide/flat-side down.
Repeat for the bottom edges.
Add a third stick in the middle.
Finish off with 2 craft sticks to either side of the middle stick.
Draw tiny nails with a silver marker.
Simply make 2 dots on each end of your 7 craft sticks.
If you covered them with washi tape, a black marker might stand out better.
tyn_section: in (0.95 cm) thick balsa wood stick
Washi tape, acrylic tape, or black coffee (optional)
